misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the Scanner's next() method will read a semantically complete 'name' (like 'Alice Smith') as a single unit because it is being assigned to a 'names' array, rather than understanding it only reads until the next whitespace.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, sc.next() is token-based, not semantics-based. It consumes the next whitespace-delimited string, regardless of whether the human developer considers that token to be a partial or complete name. This leads to a desynchronization of parallel arrays if any name contains a space.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that parallel arrays must be populated in entirely separate loops (all names first, then all scores), likely mirroring the structure of the data arrays rather than the structure of the input source.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to see that the machine can update two different memory locations (different arrays) within the same iterative block. While not logically incorrect, it suggests a mental model where the computer can only 'focus' on one data collection at a time.
